questions.question: Match the following parasites with their respective organs of locomotion: Parasite Organ of Locomotion 1. Balamuthia mandrillaris a. Flagella 2. Balantidium coli b. Cilia 3. Trichomonas vaginalis c. Pseudopod 4. Toxoplasma gondii d. No particular organ
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d Explanation: Balamuthia mandrillaris → Pseudopods Free-living amoeba causing granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE). Moves using pseudopods (temporary cytoplasmic projections). Balantidium coli → Cilia The only ciliated protozoan pathogenic to humans. Causes balantidiasis (dysentery-like illness), often acquired from pigs. Trichomonas vaginalis → Flagella Pear-shaped protozoan with multiple flagella, responsible for trichomoniasis (STD). No cyst stage (exists only in trophozoite form). Toxoplasma gondii → No particular organ An intracellular protozoan that moves via gliding motility (not a specific organ). Causes toxoplasmosis, important in immunocompromised patients and pregnancy. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8579774/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8957295/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534826/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563286/

questions.question: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive, and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear are given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Plasmodium falciparum Explanation: The clinical scenario indicates cerebral malaria. Plasmodium falciparum is one of the species of Plasmodium that causes cerebral malaria in humans characterized by high fever, headache, anorexia, nausea, anemia, hypotension, tachycardia, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, confusion, increased muscle tone, seizures, paralysis, and coma. The presence of "headphone-shaped/banana shaped" trophozoites in the blood smear is characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum, which is the causative agent of malaria. Vivax Falciparum Malariae Ovale RBC size Enlarged Normal Normal Enlarged with frayed margins Pigments Yellowish brown Dark brown Schizont Large (9-10 µ m) Fills the RBC Contains 12-24 merozoite Not seen in the periphery Small (6 µ m), almost fills the RBC and contains 8 merozoites Gametocytes Spherical (Option A) Crescentic Larger than RBC Spherical (Option C and D) Ring form 2.5 µ m Occupies I rd of RBC size Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick 1.5 µ m Occupies I of RBC size It may be Multiple forms Accole (attached to RBC membrane) Double dot/headphone shaped with fragment nucleus Band form 2.5 µ m Occupies I rd of RBC size Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick In Plasmodium falciparum, only gametocyte and ring forms are demonstrated in the PBS, as later stages of the erythrocytic cycle occur in deep vessels and not in peripheral blood.

questions.question: Identify the parasite.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Giardia lamblia Explanation: The given image is of trophozoite stage of Giardia lamblia Giardia lamblia: It includes 2 stages: Trophozoite (or vegetative form) Cysts (or cystic form). Infective form: Mature cyst Transmission: Feco oral route. Habitat: Mucosa of duodenum and upper ileum. Ingesting a minimum of 10 cysts can cause an infection in a person. Within half an hour of ingestion, the cyst hatches out into two trophozoites, which multiply successively by binary fission and colonise the duodenum. During unfavorable condition , encystment occurs and cyst are passed in stool and remain viable in soil and water for several weeks. Life cycle : Host (only human) → Contaminated food and water (faeco-oral route) → Cyst (ingested form) → excystation occurs → Trophozoite. Diagnosis: Sample: Stool Microscopy: Cyst and trophozoite are seen. Trophozoite: 2 nuclei and four pairs of flagella with pear-shaped or tennis racket-shaped. Cyst: 1-4 nuclei and no flagella. String test: A capsule will have a string, and the capsule is swallowed, then the capsule goes to duodenum and dissolves, then the string is pulled back and, a microscopic examination is done. Duodenal biopsy: Giardia lamblia is a luminal organism Organisms hanging in the lumen Sickle shaped organism is seen. Falling leaf motility is shown. Treatment: Metronidazole Tinidazole (single dose of 2g) Trichomonas vaginalis (Option B) The trophozoite of Trichomonas is a pyriform or oval-shaped organism with 4 flagella on the anterior end, and 5th flagella remain folded on the outer surface of the undulating membrane. An axosystole runs throughout the length of the body. Trypanosoma (Option C) is a hemoflagellate with 4 different morphological forms all of them containing 1 nucleus, and kinetoplast. Different forms are Amastigote, Promastigote, Epimastigote and Trypomastigote. Cyclospora (Option D) It is a coccidian Protozoa, which is usually identified by its oocysts. Sporulated oocysts of cyclospora are round in shape as well as acid-fast, but contain 2 sporocysts, with each sporocyst containing two sporozoites.

questions.question: Based on the given image, which of the following specimens would not contain filarial worms, considering the presented disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Saliva Explanation: The given image is of lymphedema of left leg seen in lymphatic filariasis aka elephantiasis occurs as a result of chronic infection of filariasis, due to lymphatic obstruction ultimately leading to swelling of the limbs. Filarial worms can be found in blood, urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid , but not in saliva. Filariasis: Agent: Wucheria bancrofti: Lymphatic filariasis Brugia malayi: Brugian/Malayan filariasis Endemic areas: Bihar, Jharkhand , Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, Gujarat Host: Definitive: Man Secondary/ intermediate: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans Mode of Transmission: Bite of the mosquito (vector) W. bancrofti: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans (polluted water) B. malayi: Mansonia (ponds, lakes) Incubation period: 8-16 months. Transmission: Cyclodevelopmental Clinical features: Asymptomatic amicrofilariae : No symptoms, smear-negative Asymptomatic microfilariae: No symptoms, smear-positive Acute stage (few months) : Fever, lymphadenitis , epididymo-orchitis. Chronic Obstructive stage (>10 years) : Hydrocele, chyluria, elephantiasis Occult stage: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (hypersensitivity reaction) with absent microfilariae. Diagnosis of filariasis 1. Thick blood film (Investigation of choice) Nocturnal microfilariae are seen in blood between 10 PM to 2 AM Lymphatic filariasis Brugian/Malayan filariasis Large, smooth (graceful) curve with countable nuclei Small, kinked at an acute angle with a long head and uncountable nuclei 2. Rapid Detection Test Also called the filarial strip test Used for monitoring , mapping, and evaluation activities 3. Membrane filter concentration method Most sensitive methods for detecting low-density microfilaraemia Require specialized equipment. 4. DEC provocation test: A single oral dose of 100mg DEC followed by blood smear after 1 hour Microfilariae can appear in the daytime. Highest specificity 5. Serological tests Cannot differentiate between past and present infection 6. Mass blood survey Thick blood films for epidemiological Survey

questions.question: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope.
questions.explanation: labeled at the base of the tube, it indicates that parasitic ova will be seen at this level when viewed under a microscope. Formol-ether sedimentation is a commonly used technique for concentrating parasites and ova from stool samples when the egg burden is low. In this technique, the stool sample is mixed with a formalin-ether solution. The high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water, the eggs sinks to the bottom. Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution. The different levels represented by markings are: Level 1: represents the topmost layer of the sample and typically contains ether. Level II: contain some debris. Level III: contains formalin. Level IV: protozoan cyst and eggs. Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method?

options.A: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
options.B: Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
options.C: Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
options.D: Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae

questions.explanation: method. It involves injecting the thorax of Aedes mosquitoes (the vector for dengue virus) with blood from a patient suspected to have dengue. The mosquitoes are then observed for viral replication and transmission, which can help confirm the diagnosis. Xenodiagnosis: Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic technique in which live vectors or organisms are used to detect the presence of an infectious agent in a host. This is particularly useful for detecting pathogens that are difficult to isolate or grow in a laboratory setting. Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC (Option A) This method involves introducing a loop of rabbit ileum (part of the small intestine) into the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract and assessing the effects of enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) on the loop. Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis (Option C) It involves injecting a hamster with a biopsy specimen from the spleen to diagnose leishmaniasis. The hamster serves as a host for the parasite, but it is not a different species used for diagnosis. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria (Option D) It involves conducting an intradermal test on guinea pigs to assess the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The guinea pigs are used as a model to evaluate the effects of the toxin, but they are not a different species used for diagnosis. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7425851/

questions.question: Which of the given statements accurately reflects the characteristics of trematodes?

options.A: Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles
options.C: Fasciola hepatica is not acquired through contaminated water
options.D: Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles Explanation: Fasciola Hepatica Fasciola hepatica, commonly known as the liver fluke, is a parasitic trematode (flatworm) that primarily infects the livers of various mammals, including humans. It causes the disease fascioliasis, leading to liver damage, biliary obstruction , and inflammatory reactions. Morphology Adult Fluke: Shape: Leaf-shaped, flat, and broad. Size: Approximately 2-3 cm in length and 1 cm in width. Color: Typically brown or grey. Distinctive Features: Cone-shaped anterior end. Two suckers, an oral sucker at the front and a ventral sucker close to it, used for attachment to host tissues. The fluke’s body is covered by a tegument (a protective outer layer) with spines aiding in attachment. Eggs: Size: Large, oval, and approximately 130-150 µm in length. Color: Yellowish-brown. Characteristics: Each egg has an operculum (a lid-like structure) at one end, which opens to release the miracidium (the larval stage). Eggs are unembryonated when passed out in feces. Life Cycle Eggs in Water Eggs are expelled in the feces of infected mammals (definitive hosts). Under suitable environmental conditions, miracidia are released from eggs after 9–15 days. Infection of Snails (Intermediate Host) Miracidia penetrate specific freshwater snails, such as Lymnaea spp. Inside the snail, they progress through stages: sporocyst, redia, and eventually cercaria. Release and Encystment Cercariae exit the snail and encyst on aquatic vegetation, transforming into metacercariae, the infective stage. Infection of Mammals (Definitive Host) Mammals, including humans, become infected by consuming contaminated water or vegetation with metacercariae. In the duodenum, metacercariae excyst, penetrate the intestinal wall, migrate to the liver, and lodge in the bile ducts, maturing into adult flukes. Clinical Presentation Acute Phase (Invasive or Hepatic Stage): Duration: Begins about 2-3 weeks post-infection and may last for several months. Symptoms: Fever, right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), and occasionally jaundice. Nausea, vomiting, and weight loss. Eosinophilia (elevated eosinophil count in blood). Chronic Phase (Biliary Stage): Duration: Occurs months to years post-infection. Symptoms: Biliary colic, obstructive jaundice, and cholangitis (inflammation of the bile ducts). Gallbladder symptoms, liver abscesses, and secondary bacterial infections in severe cases. Possible fibrosis of the bile ducts with prolonged infection. Investigations Serology: ELISA for detection of anti-Fasciola antibodies (sensitive in both acute and chronic infections). Immunoblotting can also confirm the diagnosis. Stool Examination: Microscopic detection of eggs in stool samples; however, eggs are typically not present in the acute phase and may be difficult to detect in chronic cases. Imaging: Ultrasound: Useful in detecting hepatobiliary abnormalities such as bile duct dilation or liver abscesses. CT/MRI: May show liver lesions or track the migration of larvae in the liver. Blood Tests: Eosinophilia is common in the acute phase. Liver function tests: Elevated liver enzymes, especially in chronic disease. Management Antiparasitic Treatment: Triclabendazole: The drug of choice, effective against both adult and larval stages. Dosage: Oral dose of 10-12 mg/kg, with a repeat dose after 12 hours if needed. Alternative Medications: Bithionol: Sometimes used if triclabendazole is unavailable. Incorrect Options: Schistosoma are Monoecious (Option B) Schistosoma is dioecious, i.e., males and females are separate. Fasciola Hepatica is not acquired

questions.question: A man with a fever of unknown origin has a job that requires traveling around the world. The histology of the bone marrow is shown below. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) rk39 antigen test Explanation: The given histology image of bone marrow picture histology reveals Leishman Donovan bodies, suggesting typical Leishmaniasis. Leishman Donovan bodies are macrophages-laden amastigotes , which are ovoid or rounded cells, about 2-4 µ m in size Diagnosis of Kala-azar : Depends upon direct and indirect evidences: CFT: Complement Fixation Test; CIEP: Counter Immunoelectrophoresis; DAT: Direct Agglutination Test; DNA: Deoxyribonucleic Acid; ELISA: Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay; ICT: Immunochromatographic Test; IFAT: Indirect Immunofluorescent Antibody Test; LD: Leishman-Donovan; NNN: Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle; PCR: Polymerase Chain Reaction; rK39: Recombinant Kinesin 39 Microscopy Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of kala-azar / VL Materials collected: 1. Peripheral blood smear : Peripheral blood contains the amastigotes present inside circulating monocytes. It is best to examine buffy coat smear, Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night. Blood smear test showing macrophages with amastigotes and extracellular Leishmania parasites (white arrows). 2. Bone

questions.question: What is the likely vector for the disease in a patient from Uttar Pradesh who presented with symptoms of fever, pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, peripheral smear examination showing macrophages laden with organisms containing a kinetoplast?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Sandfly Explanation: The patient described with symptoms like fever , pallor , hepatosplenomegaly , pancytopenia , and a peripheral smear showing macrophages laden with organisms containing a kinetoplast is most likely infected with Leishmania species, which cause visceral leishmaniasis (also known as Kala-azar ). The organism observed in the smear (with a kinetoplast) is characteristic of Leishmania amastigotes. Sandflies are the vector responsible for transmitting Leishmania species, including Leishmania donovani , which is the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis in India, including Uttar Pradesh. Life Cycle of Leishmania donovani Infection of the Vector: A female sandfly (e.g., Phlebotomus , Lutzomyia ) bites an infected mammal and ingests blood containing amastigotes . Development in the Sandfly: Inside the sandfly’s midgut , amastigotes transform into promastigotes , which multiply and migrate to the proboscis. Transmission to the Mammalian Host: When the sandfly bites a new host, it injects the infective promastigotes . Transformation in the Host: Promastigotes are engulfed by macrophages and transform into amastigotes , which are non-flagellated and replicate intracellularly. Replication and Dissemination: Amastigotes multiply within macrophages, causing cell lysis and releasing new amastigotes to infect other macrophages. Transmission Back to the Sandfly: If an uninfected sandfly bites the infected host, it ingests amastigotes, and the cycle continues. Clinical features of kala-azar: Onset: Insidious. The clinical illness begins with high-grade fever which may be remittent with twice daily spikes or intermittent or less commonly continuous. Night sweats Splenomegaly starts early and is progressive and massive. It is usually soft and nontender. Hepatomegaly is moderate. Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic areas except the Indian subcontinent. Skin becomes dry, rough and darkly pigmented (hence, the name kala-azar). The hair becomes thin and brittle. Cachexia with marked anaemia, emaciation and weight loss is seen. Hematological abnormalities: Anemia is most always present and is usually severe leukopenia , thrombocytopenia is associated with epistaxis, gum bleeding, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Ascites and edema may occur due to hypoalbuminemia. Renal involvement is also common. In the late stage of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, VL can present as an opportunistic infection. HIV coinfection rate is 5% in India and 20% in African countries. Secondary infections such as herpes, measles, pneumonia, tuberculosis, and bacillary dysentery may occur. Most untreated patients die in about two years due to some intercurrent disease such as dysentery, diarrhoea and tuberculosis. Child with visceral leishmaniasis with hepatosplenomegaly Diseases caused by Sandflies: Leishmania Sandfly fever caused by the Toscano virus Bunya virus causing ‘Three-day fever’ Incorrect Options: Tse-Tse fly (Option B) : The Tse-Tse fly is responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma species, such as Trypanosoma brucei , which causes sleeping sickness (trypanosomiasis), not Leishmania. Triatomine bug (Option C) : This is the vector for Trypanosoma cruzi , which causes Chagas disease .

questions.question: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having a nocturnal cough for the last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Strongylodes stercoralis Explanation: Strongyloides stercoralis is a parasitic nematode that can cause strongyloidiasis . It is known to produce larvae that can be detected in a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen. The patient's history of chronic steroid use is significant, as steroids can lead to immunosuppression, which in turn can lead to dissemination of Strongyloides stercoralis . Strongyloides stercoralis typically causes a chronic, indolent infection , which can worsen during immunosuppression or steroid therapy . This can lead to dissemination , causing symptoms like respiratory distress and eosinophilia , which are consistent with the patient's presentation of acute worsening of respiratory symptoms, nocturnal cough, and elevated eosinophils. Strongyloidiasis can involve the lungs as larvae migrate through the lungs before being coughed up and swallowed, which explains the respiratory symptoms. Rhabditiform larva Filariform larva 1st stage of the larva (L1). 3d stage of the larva (L3). Formed when eggs hatch in the small intestine. Developed from two molts of the L1 larva. Measures approximately 0.25 mm in length with a short muscul’ar double-bulb esophagus . Measures about 0.55 mm in length, characterized by a long, slender shape, uniform esophagus & notched tail . Found in feces . Seen in hyperinfection & disseminated infection may show in sputum, stool and body fluids. Diagnostic form Infective form Pathogenesis and Clinical Features of Strongyloides Stercoralis

questions.question: A patient presents with seizures, and CT head reveals multiple calcified parenchymal cysts. What is the correct management approach?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Continue antiepileptics Explanation: Multiple calcified parenchymal cysts on CT head are characteristic of Neurocysticercosis (NCC) in the inactive (calcified) stage. Seizures in calcified NCC are caused by gliotic scarring rather than active infection, so the p rimary treatment is antiepileptic therapy. Antiparasitic drugs (Albendazole, Praziquantel) are ineffective in the calcified stage and can worsen inflammation. Steroids are used only if perilesional edema is present, but they do not alter the course of calcified cysts. The combination of albendazole and praziquantel is recommended for effective treatment of multiple viable cysts (>2 cysts). Treatment of Neurocysticercosis Seizure Management : Anticonvulsant therapy is initiated upon seizure presentation. Stop if follow-up imaging shows resolution and no seizures for 24 months. Anthelmintic Therapy : Depends on the lesion stage. Cystic Lesions Treatment : Albendazole : Drug of choice for parenchymal Neurocysticercosis (15 mg/kg daily for 10-14 days). Recommended for 1-2 parenchymal cysts. Praziquantel : Alternative option (50 mg/kg in 3 divided doses daily for 10 days). Albendazole + Praziquantel : For >2 viable cysts (Praziquantel: 50 mg/kg/day for 10-14 days). Prednisolone: 10 mg three times daily for 14 days, starting 1 day before Albendazole or Praziquantel. Given to suppress the inflammation during the natural course of the disease. Stages of Cysts : Viable Cysts : Treated with anticysticidal therapy. Vesicular & Colloidal Stages : Treated with anticysticidal therapy. Granulonodular Stage : Some experts recommend treatment. Calcified Lesions : Do not require treatment with anticysticidal therapy. Small, Solitary Cerebral Cysts : Often resolve without treatment. Operative Intervention : Indicated for hydrocephalus. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1120 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 298 Neurocysticercosis - PMC Neurocysticercosis Diagnosis and Treatment of Neurocysticercosis - PMC

questions.question: The life cycle of an organism is given below. Identify the vector involved in its transmission.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Trombiculid mite Explanation: Trombiculid mites (chigger mites) are the vectors for Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus . Scrub typhus Causative agent Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer . Vector Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite) Pathophysiology Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes. It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites. Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans . Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis . Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission . Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash. Clinical features The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles. Non-specific manifestations may appear early

questions.question: Match the following parasites with their respective intermediate hosts: Parasite Host 1. Diphyllobothrium a. Sheep 2. Paragonimus b. Crab 3. Brugia c. Cyclops 4. Fasciola d. Mosquitoes
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a Explanation: Diphyllobothrium (Fish Tapeworm) → Cyclops The first intermediate host is Cyclops (Copepod, a freshwater crustacean). The second intermediate host is freshwater fish. Humans acquire infection by consuming undercooked freshwater fish. Paragonimus (Lung Fluke) → Crab The first intermediate host is snail. The second intermediate host is crabs or crayfish. Humans acquire infection by consuming raw or undercooked crabs. Brugia (Causes Lymphatic Filariasis) → Mosquitoes Brugia malayi & Brugia timori are transmitted by mosquitoes (Mansonia, Anopheles, Aedes). The mosquito serves as the intermediate host and vector. Fasciola (Liver Fluke) → Sheep The definitive host is sheep, cattle, or humans. The intermediate host is aquatic snails. Humans acquire infection by consuming contaminated aquatic plants like watercress. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK540971/ https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31297761/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537032/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK556012/

questions.question: Identify the organism shown in this image.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Ascaris lumbricoides Explanation: The given image shows Ascaris lumbricoides. The female Ascaris lumbricoides is identified by a straight conical posterior end & a vulvar groove, distinguishing it from the male, which has a ventrally curved posterior end. Females are also larger, measuring 20-40 cm, compared to males at 15-30 cm Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides) Habitat Adult worms reside in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum) and are the largest nematode parasites in humans. Morphology Adult Worms : Large, cylindrical, with tapering ends and pale pink color that turns white outside the body. Male Worms : Smaller than females (15-30 cm long, 2-4 mm thick) A ventrally curved posterior end and two copulatory spicules. Female Worms : Larger than males Straight , conical posterior end & a vulvar groove aiding in mating. Reproduction A single female can lay up to 200,000 eggs daily, which are expelled in the feces. Host Humans only Infective Form Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae. Transmission Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water. Incorrect Options: Strongyloides stercoralis (Option A) : This nematode is much smaller and thread-like. It primarily affects the small intestine and is diagnosed via larvae in stool rather than large adult worms. It can cause autoinfection, leading to hyperinfection syndrome in immunocompromised individuals. Enterobius vermicularis (Option B): Also known as the pinworm, it is much smaller (~1 cm) and resides in the perianal region. It causes perianal itching (especially at night), and diagnosis is confirmed using the Scotch tape test to detect eggs. Ancylostoma duodenale (Option C): This is a hookworm, characterized by its curved morphology and cutting plates/teeth. It causes iron deficiency anemia due to chronic blood loss in the intestines. Infection occurs via skin penetration from contaminated soil.

questions.question: What is the causative organism for the condition shown in the image below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Echinococcus granulosus Explanation: Echinococcus granulosus causes hydatid cyst disease, primarily affecting the liver (most common) and lungs. The cysts have a fluid-filled, multilayered wall and may show a "water lily" sign if ruptured. Humans are accidental hosts, acquiring infection through ingestion of eggs from dog feces. Echinococcus granulosus: Other name Dog tapeworm Definitive Host Dog (optimal host), wolf, jackal and fox Intermediate Host Sheep and cattle Accidental Intermediate Host Man (Harbors larval stage, not adult form) Infective Form Embryonated egg Mode of Infection Ingestion of the eggs due to: Intimate handling of infected dogs Eating raw vegetables or other food items contaminated with dog feces Eggs Ovoid in shape and brown in color Contains an embryo with three pairs of hooklets Larva Represent structure of scolex of adult worm and remains invaginated within a vesicular body. Adult Worm Consist of scolex, a short neck and strobila Scolex is pyriform, with four suckers and prominent rostellum bearing two circular rows of hooklets. Life Cycle: Schistosoma japonicum (Option B): This trematode causes intestinal and hepatosplenic schistosomiasis, leading to periportal fibrosis (Symmer’s pipestem fibrosis) and portal hypertension. It does not form cystic lesions. Echinococcus multilocularis (Option C): This species causes alveolar echinococcosis , a more aggressive form resembling malignant hepatic infiltration rather than a well-defined cystic lesion. Schistosoma mansoni (Option D): It causes hepatic schistosomiasis, characterized by eggs in the liver leading to granulomatous inflammation, but does not produce cystic lesions.

questions.question: A female patient from the northeastern part of the country presents with progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. Examination reveals proximal limb swelling more than distal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Night blood test for worms Explanation: The northeastern part of the country is endemic for lymphatic filariasis (Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi), which causes proximal limb lymphedema due to lymphatic obstruction. Microfilariae exhibit nocturnal periodicity, making a night blood test the preferred initial investigation. Filariasis: Agent: Wucheria bancrofti: Lymphatic filariasis Brugia malayi: Brugian/Malayan filariasis Endemic areas: Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, Gujarat Host: Definitive: Man Secondary/ intermediate: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans Mode of Transmission: Bite of the mosquito (vector) W. bancrofti: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans (polluted water) B. malayi: Mansonia (ponds, lakes) Incubation period: 8-16 months. Transmission: Cyclodevelopmental Clinical features: Asymptomatic amicrofilariae: No symptoms, smear-negative Asymptomatic microfilariae: No symptoms, smear-positive Acute stage (few months): Fever, lymphadenitis, epididymo-orchitis. Chronic Obstructive stage (>10 years): Hydrocele, chyluria, elephantiasis Occult stage: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (hypersensitivity reaction) with absent microfilariae Life Cycle of Filaria (Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi): Lab Diagnosis: 1. Demonstration of Microfilaria: In blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix or hydrocele fluid. Best collect night blood samples between 10pm and 4 am. Microfilaria can be seen in unstained as well as stained specimens. Staining is performed using Giemsa, Leishman, or polychrome methylene blue. Concentration Techniques: Done if microfilaria density is low Knott’s concentration technique Nucleopore filtration Diethylcarbamazine provocation test (DCT): Small dose of DEC given (2 mg/kg body weight) Forces microfilaria to appear in peripheral blood during daytime. Quantitative buffy coat 2. Ultrasonography: Identify motile adult worms in the scrotum and female breast within dilated lymphatics, known as the "filaria dance sign." 3. Hemogram: Eosinophilia Elevated serum IgE levels 4. Demonstration of Antibody: Cannot distinguish between current and past infections. 5. Demonstration of Circulating Antigen: Highly sensitive and specific Trop-bio test: Semiquantitative sandwich ELISA ELISA: To detect specific IgG4 antibody against W.bancrofti antigen ( WbSXP-1 ) Immunochromatographic test (ICT): Detects soluble W.bancrofti antigen using monoclonal antibody ( AD12 ) in serum. Treatment: Drug of Choice: Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) Mass drug therapy is given as either: DEC alone DEC + Albendazole DEC + Ivermectin Echocardiography (Option A): Cardiac conditions such as heart failure or superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome can cause limb swelling. However, these usually present with bilateral swelling and additional systemic symptoms. Given the patient's regional background and asymmetric proximal swelling, filariasis is a more likely cause. Duplex venous scan of limbs (Option C): A venous scan is useful in detecting deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which typically causes distal rather than proximal limb swelling. In this case, lymphatic obstruction is a more likely cause. ECG (Option D): Although the patient has a history of coronary artery disease, ECG does not

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with chronic watery diarrhea. The histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Giardia lamblia Explanation: Giardia lamblia is a flagellated protozoan parasite commonly associated with contaminated water sources. It causes symptoms such as foul-smelling, greasy diarrhoea, bloating, and abdominal cramps. Biopsy findings may reveal luminal organisms attached to the intestinal epithelium, causing blunting of the villi and inflammation without tissue invasion. The characteristic appearance of Giardia trophozoites on biopsy is often described as resembling "falling leaves" due to their distinctive shape and attachment pattern. Entamoeba histolytica (Option B): Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that can cause amoebic dysentery. Histological examination would typically show invasive trophozoites within the colonic mucosa, unlike the luminal organisms in this case. Microsporidia (Option C): Causes chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS). Not typically seen in the duodenum; would show spore forms on histology, but not characteristic of the watery diarrhea here. Cryptosporidia (Option D): Cryptosporidium is a protozoan parasite that can cause watery diarrhoea, especially in immunocompromised individuals. The organisms are typically small, round oocysts. However, the histological findings of luminal organisms without tissue invasion are more typical of Giardia lamblia.

questions.question: Which of the following causative agents is commonly transmitted by soil and is characterized by the egg in stool, as shown in the image below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Trichuris trichiura Explanation: Trichuris trichiura (Whipworm) is a soil-transmitted helminth that infects humans via ingestion of embryonated eggs from contaminated soil. The diagnostic feature is its characteristic barrel-shaped eggs with bipolar plugs (seen in stool examination). It causes trichuriasis, presenting with: Chronic diarrhea Iron deficiency anemia Rectal prolapse (in severe cases, especially in children) Trichuris trichiura / Whip worm Morphology Adult worm The male worm is 30-45 mm long. The female worm is 40-50 mm long (slightly larger). Appearance: Flesh-colored. Whip-shaped: anterior (3/5) thin and thread-like; posterior (2/5) thick and fleshy (like a handle). The end of the male worms is coiled ventrally. The end of the female worm is straight, blunt, and rounded. Body structure: The anterior portion contains a capillary esophagus. The posterior part contains the intestines and reproductive organs. Lifespan: 5-10 years. Eggs Characteristics: The eggs appear brown as they are bile-stained. They are barrel-shaped . They have a triple shell with a brown outer layer and a colorless mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. Infectivity: Freshly passed eggs contain an unsegmented ovum and are not infective for humans. The egg floats in a saturated salt solution. The fertilized female lays about 5,000 eggs per day. Epidemiology Distribution: Worldwide, with higher prevalence in tropical regions. Common in tropical Africa, South America, and Southeast Asia. Widespread

questions.question: A 30-year-old female from a tribal area presents with fever for the last 3 days. A peripheral smear confirms the diagnosis of malaria. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Plasmodium falciparum Explanation: Plasmodium falciparum is the most common cause of malaria in tribal and endemic areas of India, particularly in regions with high transmission rates. It causes severe malaria with complications such as cerebral malaria, renal failure, and severe anemia. It is responsible for most fatal cases of malaria worldwide. Vivax (Option A ruled out) Falciparum (Option A) Malariae (Option B ruled out) Ovale (Option C ruled out) RBC size Enlarged Normal Normal Enlarged with frayed margins Pigments Yellowish brown Dark brown Schizont Large (9-10 µ m) Fills the RBC Contains 12-24 merozoite Not seen in the periphery Small (6 µ m), almost fills the RBC and contains 8 merozoites Gametocytes Spherical Crescentic Larger than RBC Spherical Ring form 2.5 µ m Occupies I rd of RBC size Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick 1.5 µ m Occupies I of RBC size It may be Multiple forms Accole (attached to RBC membrane) Double dot/headphone shaped with fragment nucleus Band form 2.5 µ m Occupies I rd of RBC size Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick In Plasmodium falciparum, only gametocyte and ring forms are demonstrated in the PBS, as later stages of the erythrocytic cycle occur in deep vessels and not in peripheral blood.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Whipworm Explanation: Whipworm (Trichuris trichiura) eggs are barrel-shaped with bipolar plugs (mucoid plugs at both ends) as shown in the image. Trichuris trichiura / Whip worm Morphology Adult worm The male worm is 30-45 mm long. The female worm is 40-50 mm long (slightly larger). Appearance: Flesh-colored. Whip-shaped: anterior (3/5) thin and thread-like; posterior (2/5) thick and fleshy (like a handle). The end of the male worms is coiled ventrally. The end of the female worm is straight, blunt, and rounded. Body structure: The anterior portion contains a capillary esophagus. The posterior part contains the intestines and reproductive organs. Lifespan: 5-10 years. Eggs Characteristics: The eggs appear brown as they are bile-stained. They are barrel-shaped . They have a triple shell with a brown outer layer and a colorless mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. Infectivity: Freshly passed eggs contain an unsegmented ovum and are not infective for humans. The egg floats in a saturated salt solution. The fertilized female lays about 5,000 eggs per day. Epidemiology Distribution: Worldwide, with higher prevalence in tropical regions. Common in tropical Africa, South America, and Southeast Asia. Widespread in India. Prevalence: An estimated 800 million people are infected globally. While whipworm infections are frequent, whipworm disease is relatively rare. Pathogenicity: The incubation period is 70 to 90 days. questions.question: What is the average incubation period of plasmodium falciparum?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 12 Explanation: For Plasmodium falciparum , the average incubation period is typically around 12 days from the time of infection until the onset of symptoms. The parasite binds to RBCs using the Basigin receptor (CD147), facilitating its entry into the cells. Properties of different species of Plasmodium: Properties P.vivax P.ovale P.falciparum P.malariae Relapse (Hypnozoites) Seen Seen Not seen Not seen Recrudescence Not seen Not seen Seen Seen Preference Reticulocytes Reticulocytes Young erythrocytes Old erythrocytes Erythrocytic Cycle 48 hours 48 hours 36–48 hours 72 hours Prepatent Period 8 days 9 days 5 days 13 days Incubation Period 12- 17 days 14-17 days 12 days 28-30 days Stages found in peripheral blood Trophozoite, schizonts, gametocytes As in vivax Ring form, accole form, gametocytes Band forms Infected erythrocyte Enlarged pale with Schuffner's dots Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Schuffner's dots (Jame's dots) Normal size, Maurer's cleft Normal size, Ziemann's stippling Gametocyte Spherical, fills the cell Similar to but smaller than vivax Crescent, Banana shaped Similar to but smaller than vivax Colour of pigment Yellowish-brown Yellowish-brown Black Dark brown Prepatent period: The time from the entry of the parasite into the host until it is detectable in peripheral blood. Incubation period: Time interval from the entry of the parasite until the appearance of the first clinical symptoms. Receptors on RBC: Plasmodium vivax: Binds to Duffy antigen (also known as Duffy blood group antigen) on the surface of red blood cells (RBCs) Plasmodium falciparum: Binds to Basigin (also known as CD147) , a protein expressed on the surface of RBCs Options B, C, & D are incorrect. Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page 77 Apurba S Sastry, Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 348 BASIGIN is a receptor essential for erythrocyte invasion by Plasmodium falciparum - PMC

questions.question: A 55 year old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile at 40 degree C, hypotensive, and has tachycardia. The blood smear of this patient is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Plasmodium falciparum Explanation: Based on the description of the patient's symptoms (fever, hypotension, tachycardia) and the blood smear findings, Plasmodium falciparum is the most likely causative agent. P. falciparum is known to cause severe malaria , which can present with high fever, hypotension , tachycardia , and other complications like cerebral malaria and organ dysfunction . The Microscopic findings described—infected red blood cells of various sizes, multiple ring forms within single red blood cells, and the presence of crescentic (banana-shaped) gametocytes—are characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum. The blood smear for P. vivax often shows larger trophozoites with a larger, irregular-shaped ring and sometimes a "schuffner's dots" characteristic, which isn't described in the scenario. questions.question: Which organism is the cause of perianal itching in a child who experiences symptoms primarily at night, leading to sleep disturbances? The eggs of the responsible organism can be observed in the accompanying image.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Enterobius vermicularis Explanation: The parasite infestation in the given scenario is of Enterobius vermicularis or the pinworm which causes intense itching in the perianal region due to the female worm laying eggs in this region at night. The infective stage of this is the embryonated egg . The eggs are often observed on the perianal skin, and when the child scratches the area, they can spread the eggs to others or other surfaces. The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained Enterobius vermicularis / Pinworm / Threadworm Epidemiology: The most common age group being school children . Infections can persist for years due to auto-infective cycles . Factors contributing to infection include: Overcrowding Impaired hygiene Poor personal care practices (such as nail-biting and inadequate handwashing). Morphology Adult worm The adults are short, white, and fusiform, resembling bits of white thread. The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like structures called cervical alae, which are transversely striated. Female worm Females are long. The posterior third tapers into a thin, pointed, pin-like tail. Females are oviparous. Male worm The posterior end is tightly curved ventrally, sharply truncated, and has a prominent copulatory spicule. Eggs The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained They float in saturated salt solution and have an elongated ovoid shape. Each egg contains a tadpole-shaped, coiled embryo that becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited . Scotch-tape test: A piece of clear tape is pressed against the skin around the anus to collect eggs, typically overnight. The tape is then examined under a microscope for pinworm eggs. Life cycle: Enterobius vermicularis spends the entire lifecycle in humans . It has no intermediate hosts and does not undergo systemic migration. The eggs hatch in the intestine, and the larvae enter the caecum and mature into adults. The male worm does not migrate and most often dies after mating and is passed in the feces. The female worm migrates to the rectum from the colon and travels to the perianal skin at night to lay its sticky eggs and dies after laying all eggs or gets crushed due to scratching. Pathogenicity: The embryonated egg is the infective form. The disease thus caused is called enterobiasis, which is more common in children than in adults. It affects females > males. The infection occurs in two ways: Exogenous autoinfection is where the eggs are transferred from the perianal region to the mouth by nails after scratching the region. Endogenous autoinfection/retro-infection is where the larva migrates retrograde and travels back into the colon after hatching in the perianal skin. Incorrect Options: Trichuris trichiura (Option B) (whipworm): While whipworms can infect the intestines, they are not typically associated with perianal itching or the nocturnal symptoms described. Their main symptoms involve abdominal pain, diarrhea, and occasionally rectal prolapse. Trichinella spiralis (Option C) : This parasite causes trichinosis , which is typically associated with consuming undercooked pork or wild game. The primary symptoms are muscle pain and swelling, not perianal itching. Strongyloides stercoralis (Option D) : This parasite causes strongyloidiasis , which typically presents with symptoms like abdominal pain , diarrhea , and skin rashes , but not specifically with perianal itching .

questions.question: What is the underlying cause of the symptoms exhibited by a 55-year-old male, including fever, fatigue, and abnormal vital signs, along with the identification of the causative agent based on the microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Plasmodium falciparum: Explanation: Plasmodium falciparum is the causative agent of severe malaria , which can present with symptoms like fever , fatigue , abnormal vital signs (such as hypotension or tachycardia), and in some cases, organ failure or cerebral malaria . It is the most dangerous of the Plasmodium species and can cause life-threatening complications, especially if not treated promptly. The microscopic findings described—infected red blood cells of various sizes, multiple ring forms within single red blood cells, and the presence of crescentic (banana-shaped) gametocytes—are characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum .
